title: How to Make Chickpea Burgers

steps.headline: In a food processor, blend chickpeas, yoghurt, curry powder, breadcrumbs & the egg until well combined.
steps.description: You aren't after a smooth paste, but a paste that still has some texture in it. The goal is to observe when it start to form a mass in the processor bowl as that's the sign that the chickpeas are processed enough to be able to form burgers. If your paste is too coarse or too dry, they may fall apart when cooking.

steps.headline: Transfer to a bowl, add herbs and spring onions and season well with salt and pepper.
steps.description: Additional seasonings to taste can include - some lemon or lime zest, freshly chopped chilli.

steps.headline: Make the paste into burgers, balls, sausages or patties and put aside on a lined tray.
steps.description: Chill in the fridge until needed, or at least 10 minutes. This makes them more stable for frying. At the same time, make your salad, prepare your breads and everything you wish to serve with these.

steps.headline: Heat a frying pan (preferably non stick, but not essential), with 1 tablespoon of oil.
steps.description: A large flat BBQ plate or electric frypan is easier for larger burgers.

steps.headline: When the pan is hot enough to fry, add your burgers or patties.
steps.description: Fry until golden and keep hot. If you are cooking a lot of these, then put the first batches to stay hot in the oven. Turn only once if you can help it - larger, thinner burgers are more likely to break than smaller patties.

steps.headline: Serve and enjoy.
steps.description: Leftover cooked rissoles are excellent cold for lunch on a hot day, or as an appetizer with a dipping sauce.

text: In a food processor, blend chickpeas, yoghurt, curry powder, breadcrumbs & the egg until well combined. You aren't after a smooth paste, but a paste that still has some texture in it. The goal is to observe when it start to form a mass in the processor bowl as that's the sign that the chickpeas are processed enough to be able to form burgers. If your paste is too coarse or too dry, they may fall apart when cooking. Transfer to a bowl, add herbs and spring onions and season well with salt and pepper. Additional seasonings to taste can include - some lemon or lime zest, freshly chopped chilli. Make the paste into burgers, balls, sausages or patties and put aside on a lined tray. Chill in the fridge until needed, or at least 10 minutes. This makes them more stable for frying. At the same time, make your salad, prepare your breads and everything you wish to serve with these. Heat a frying pan (preferably non stick, but not essential), with 1 tablespoon of oil. A large flat BBQ plate or electric frypan is easier for larger burgers. When the pan is hot enough to fry, add your burgers or patties. Fry until golden and keep hot. If you are cooking a lot of these, then put the first batches to stay hot in the oven. Turn only once if you can help it - larger, thinner burgers are more likely to break than smaller patties. Serve and enjoy. Leftover cooked rissoles are excellent cold for lunch on a hot day, or as an appetizer with a dipping sauce. Finished.
